reviews.review:
How to drive in Half Life 2: Episode 2

1. Drive forward
2. Stop
3. Pick up gnome
4. Get in car with gnome
5. Repeat

Congratulations! You're driving!

Half-Life 2 Episode Two is the second episodic continuation of the Half-Life 2 series, taking place directly after the destabilization of the Dark Fusion reactor of the citadel and the escape from City 17, taking place within the Alpines of Eastern Europe. Within the alpines, Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance must make their way to White Forest, a former Soviet ballistic missile silo complex now being used as the Resistance base of operations for firing a rocket to destroy the Combine Superportal all the while being hunted by the Combines forces ceaseless campaign to subjugate humanity within the ravaged outlands, providing perfect territory to hunt down and trap the unwary around every corner. Half-Life 2 Episode Two is a very treacherous and tense title, with a much more open environment opposed to City 17s claustrophobic, urban setting, and lacks optional item caches once found prominently throughout the environments except the Antlion Nests and Muscle Car radar section, but ends on a dramatic cliffhangar like the original Half-Life 2 and Half-Life 2 Episode One. The idea of being the hunted in the Alpines is an incredibly fun detail, and offers strategization more notable with the inclusion of the open environments to outsmart and counterattack the combine, and battle the Combines Hunters, and later on Striders. Half-Life 2 Episode Two is much longer than Half-Life 2 Episode One, and is two thirds as long as Half-Life 2. It is an amazing continuation, and I would defintently recommend this game, and would like to see more of this in the future.
the best paid game ever and when i downloaded this game it also down loaded hl2

El final a medias más laureado de la historia de los videojuegos. Jugarlo te hará entender por qué la gente es tan cansina con querer que saquen Half-Life 3 y es que nos dejan verdaderamente a medias con el final de esta expansión, la última hasta la fecha, de Half-Life 2. Un final que no hará más que confirmarnos que estamos ante un juegazo como sólo unos pocos pueden serlo a juicio de la mayoría de los que caen en sus redes.

Y es que esta saga se merece un monumento a petición popular, donde ir a celebrar las victorias del equipo de fútbol de turno y a donde se peregrine desde todas partes del mundo para hacerse la típica foto en postura absurda con un paraguas a modo de palanca y un cangrejo de goma por los aires.

Señor Newell, coja esa nueva versión del Source que acaba de sacar y haga ya el Half-Life 3, que los trozos de uñas mordidas de los que soñamos con el Borealis se cuentan por toneladas.
[i]Лучшая, во всём, и везде. Теперь с высоко поднятой головой как все преданые фанаты, буду ждать возвращение молчаливого Фримена.[/i] 10 [strike]эпизодов[/strike] из 10.

Enter, the furry "lifestylers." These are the ones that have gone too far with the fandom, making animal noises and flat out advertising their furry status right out in the open, and I don't mean harmlessly with just their furry avatar, I mean with full on personal details. These things range from "mate" status with other furries, sexual preferences and even a big list of "pets" and "masters" or even their kinks. This particular aspect of the fandom is what frankly pisses me off. We don't need to know this shit, so keep that to yourselves or at the very least, in a restricted realm specifically meant for that. Steam is NOT that place. What's worse is, after spouting their inner most hideous personal lives with everyone, they tell the disgusted people to go fuck themselves and then to respect them for who they are. Sorry, that's now how the world works. This is no better than a gay guy walking into work for his first day and advertises his sexual orientation, his boyfriend status and how he likes it in bed. Again, nobody needs to know that. As far as I've seen, you don't hear a straight person going on about that un-provoked, so frankly, knock that shit off, act like the rest of us when expected and maybe the rest of us can accept you a whole lot easier. Oh, and let's not forget the ones that honestly believe being a furry makes hate upon them racism. Furry is not a race and you know it, I shouldn't have to make points in my favor on this. This is a FANDOM, people. It may be amusing to escape every now and again to your character in the proper realm, but that does not make you a full-time animal and to think so is ludicrous. If a Harry Potter fan went around in public thinking they can blow people away with a wand, they will get a wedgie just as fast as those who think acting like a constantly, sexually frustrated animal in the improper realm is cute and acceptable.

Score: 10/10
This is the continuation of the HL2 (Half Life 2) story where it left off in episode 1. There is a commentary track by Gabe Newell where he says this is the midpoint in the episode trilogy meaning there is supposed to be an episode 3. As of 2015 there is no episode 3.

In this episode we see the continuation of the story of Gordon Freeman from the end of HL2 episode 1. I will avoid spoilers. This is the adventure of Gordon and Alyx as they escape the large urban areas to avoid the villains and set out to live in peace. I enjoyed the story elements and I greatly enjoy the soldier style game play which this has in abundance. I enjoy less the maze type puzzles and did not have much fun in the bug tunnels. Some folks may like that others may not. If you can just get past it the game picks up again. 

The hooks in this episode for me were the new style of scripted survival style events. I enjoy having to fend off waves of enemies and this trope can be done well or poorly. Here it is done well and I did not find myself getting bored.

If you have enjoyed the Half Life lore and story up to this point this episode will not disappoint. I had a great time and enjoy playing through it from time to time.

-	Enjoy.
It is not game of the year nor century nor millenium. It is game of The history.

Half-Life 2: Episode Two is the second story expansion to the original Half-Life 2 by Valve. After escaping from City 17 and the massive explosion that consumed it, Gordon Freeman and Alyx decide to reach the other rebel forces in their secret base in the White Forest area.

As far as gameplay and main structure goes, Episode Two is very similar to the first one: you will basically play a story-driven DLC for four hours or so and be challenged by several gameplay changes and enemies you'll have to overcome in order to advance. If anything, Episode Two is much more action-driven than Episode One: on top of having nearly all your weaponry from the original Half-Life 2, the DLC introduced the toughest enemies in the series yet. It's also worth mentioning that the second episode spots two incredibly nasty achievements, which are a chore to unlock in themselves. 
As far as story and environments go, Episode Two takes place in entirely new areas from the main game and a more emotional, increasingly intensive plot.

Half-Life 2: Episode Two, much like its predecessor, is a great addition to the original Half-Life 2 and filled with very high quality content

This game may not be as revolutionary as Half-Life 2. But damn is it a hell lot better(don't get me wrong, Half-Life 2 was f-cking awesome but episode 2 was even better). The Suit system have been rework. For the first time in Half-Life history there was a lot more to the story and a lot of things are being explained. There are new enemies and new gameplay mechanics. Its actually pretty long for an "episode", in fact it could be a full game. The one and only problem is that it ended with unfinished stories and a cliff hanger, and there is no sequel...

The second in an AWOL trilogy of episodic games comprising the third entry in the [i]Half-Life[/i] series, [i]Episode Two[/i] does a good job of filtering the [i]Half-Life 2[/i] formula through a different lens. This time around that lens is open world flavour. Not the shitty type of open world, mind you ([i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] didn’t come out for another month), but the type with big open levels that are actually designed coherently. The result is a game that has open gameplay and large areas, but still plays like a video game (gasp) and not an exercise in following waypoints. Actually, [i]Episode Two[/i] doesn’t have waypoints, and the compass that’s been added to the UI only points to important items nearby, not the actual objective. It may be a shock to some, but the way forward, as has always been the case for [i]Half-Life[/i], is made clear by level design cues. If [i]Episode One[/i] was ‘Anticitizen One’ from [i]Half-Life 2[/i] stretched into an entire game, [i]Episode Two[/i] gives the same treatment to ‘Highway 17’, planting you in the seat of a heavily modified muscle car and pointing you vaguely in the direction of White Forest, a Soviet-era ICBM silo commandeered by Resistance forces. The idea is we can use the data stolen in [i]Episode One[/i]` to cut off Combine forces on Earth, provided we can reach White Forest ASAP (Dropbox and Google Drive were obviously the first to go after an alien invasion). Valve seems to really enjoy the type of hours-long chase across a large area (à la [i]Mad Max: Fury Road[/i]) that both [i]Half-Life 2[/i] episodes essentially boil down to, and for good reason - being on the run is exhilarating. It’s established that this time around we’re facing the bulk of Combine forces fleeing City 17, a ramp up in challenge that’s made apparent through multiple seemingly hopeless standoffs against squads of soldiers and altogether too many helicopters.

That’s not to say we’ve lost the gameplay variety that made [i]Half-Life 2[/i] fun; we’ll still occasionally be dropped into a ditch full of zombies and radioactive waste in the dark, and antlions appear in greater numbers than before in an old mine shaft connecting to an expansive hive of the things. The open-endedness of the muscle car chapters doesn’t really permeate throughout the game, as we’re still relegated to infested mine tunnels and caves for prolonged sections. It’s clearly more of a different spin on the [i]Half-Life 2[/i] structure than a totally new type of game, which works well in this case since [i]Half-Life 2[/i] was the equivalent of Christ descending from the heavens and declaring “thou shalt shoot Nazi aliens”. The whole linear action style is still the core of the gameplay, but it’s almost like it’s been focused in a different direction. [i]Half-Life 2[/i], for example, was largely about moving through an area and taking out enemies as an obstacle to your progress. [i]Episode One[/i] was similar, but [i]Episode Two[/i] seems to be more subtle about it. What will often happen is you’ll be driving through the woods along a quiet little road when you’ll come to a little cluster of buildings. You’ll go inside and explore as you normally would, but then you’ll come back out and find that there are horrible nightmare creatures in the area now and oh fuck they’re coming and you’d better hide. [i]Episode Two[/i] seems to be more heavy on the atmosphere than previous games, and when the atmosphere isn’t ‘incredibly fast-paced action’, it’s ‘creeping dread and the sense that you’re being watched’, which I’m a big fan of. It’s more about shootouts from a defensive position this time around, all of which comes to a head in the last level, which may be the best combat scenario in the franchise [i]from an atmospheric perspective[/i]. The actual mechanics of it are a little clunkier, what with the Magnusson device and all its frustrating jank.

Speaking of jank, let’s talk characters. Like in [i]Episode One[/i], we’re stuck with Alyx Vance for more or less the whole game, which grates less this time around because of how often you can’t hear her over the roar of the engine. Still, the character interactions are more or less fine, save for the newly introduced Dr. Magnusson, whose introduction to the series is about as smooth and effective as his device. Everyone pretends he’s been around this whole time, you’re left confused, and every time he speaks you have to try pretty hard not to think about how he’s literally just a replacement for the tension that was lost when the one character with different views to the rest fucked off to the Arctic. The story’s still pretty good though. It’s nice to see something that’s been established for some time, like all the little bases set up in the woods that have clearly been used before we got here. It’s a change of pace from [i]Half-Life 2[/i] where everything was ramshackle and in states of disrepair or [i]Episode One[/i] where the entire place felt like it was going to explode at any moment. [i]Episode Two[/i] has the unfortunate role of unexpectedly being the last game in the series but also doing more setup for the next chapter than any previous. In the last few levels we’re basically told what we’re doing next and then it ends, which adds to the frustration of the last game having drowned in an ocean of Steam money. Still, one shouldn’t look at this as a criticism of [i]Episode Two[/i]. It’s fast-paced, atmospheric and masterfully designed. In short it’s a celebration of the best parts of [i]Half-Life 2[/i] that greatly benefits from being a bit longer than [i]Episode One[/i] and having more than one plot point.

Half-Life 2: Episode Two славится открытым пространством, что дает свободным путешествием на авто. Продолжение приключений Гордона с Аликс, новые локации, а также Лесная битва в Белой роще - все это и многое другое не даст нам заскучать на протяжении 5-8 часов.
●С момента выпуска второго эпизода прошло много лет, но от разработчиков нету внятных сообщений о продолжении. По ходу сюжета мы узнали ответы на интересующие нас вопросы, но большинство из них остались без ответа. С 1998 года все задаются вопросом:
КТО ЖЕ ТАКОЙ G-MAN?

Stunning graphics and sceneries especially White Forest and look back view over river to mountain. And final fight with Striders is very immersing. You need to act fast, adrenaline is pumping and when you get into it you actually enjoy last couple of striders without tension. I was playing on dual monitors just to enjoy this beautiful graphics across two 24" monitors, and bring immersion to next level, even though dual monitors are not preferred for FPS shooters.
After playing HL2 both episodes you get feeling that more work has been done on art and graphics details than on story line, which has resulted in very beautiful but short game. You can't wait for more, first Half Life has enormous story line and many chapters.

I have a dream.

I have a dream that one day Gaben will rise from his office chair and shout ''Half Life 3 is finally here!''.

I have a dream that one day bronies and furries, console peasants and PC masters will sit together at the table of fellowship and play Half Life 3.

I have a dream that one day, even Gaben, his lips so utterly sealed on the fate of the franchise, will proclaim that the wait is over.

I have a dream that one day Half Life 3 will sit in my Steam library, shining forth like a beacon for all to see.

I have a dream that one day my children, my grandchildren and my great-grandchildren will each own their own copy of Half Life 3.

For I have a dream that one day I will be granted the honour of picking up the crowbar and beating scores of headcrabs with it.

For I have a dream that one day that every human on this Earth - Caucasian, Negro, Hispanic or otherwise - will be granted the honour of experiencing Half Life 3 for themselves.

This is our hope, and this is the hope that I live with.

And if this Earth is to be a heavenly Earth, then this must be true.

So let Half Life 3 be announced from The North!

Let Half Life 3 be announced from The South!

Let Half Life 3 be announced from The East!

Let Half Life 3 be announced from The West!

May every corner of this good Earth experience the joy of Half Life 3 in their own hands!

And when this happens, when Gaben bestows upon us Half Life 3, let it be announced from every metropolis, every city, every town, every village, every square inch of Earth! For when that day is finally upon us, let every individual of every race, creed and likewise finally play Half Life 3!

For when that day is upon us, we shall join our hands together and sing:

''Half Life 3 is here at last!''

''Thank God Almighty, Half Life 3 is here at last!''

[h1] Это еще не конец ! [/h1]

[b] Эпизод 2 продолжение эпизода 1, где вы, продолжаете свое интересное приключения. Гордон Фримен и Аликс Вэнс наконец то таки покидают Сити - 17 в тот самый момент, когда Цитадель взлетела на воздух от взрыва неведомой силы. [/b]

[i] К счастью, в эту часть сделали нововведения, такие как: Охотник, Рабочий муравьиный лев, Страж гнезда муравьиных львов и т.д. Добавили и новый транспорт, внедорожник Dodge Charger, на котором вы еще быстрее ездите и лучше управляйте. Ну а из оружий разве что появились новые мины, которые нам дадут под конец игры опробовать. Как не как, хоть и мало чего добавили, но все же оригинально и свежо в отличии от 1 эпизода Half-Life. 

Ну и в отличии от 1 эпизода, который на год раньше вышел, здесь улучшена физика, улучшена графика, освещение с затемнением, ну и в конце концов лучше сюжет. Впрочем, последний к сожалению эпизод получился в разы лучше чем предыдущий. К ознакомлению не задумываясь стоит ! [/i]

Понятно, рекомендовать покупать или не покупать второй эпизод просто глупо: те, кому нравится серия купят продолжение, тому, кому все равно - все равно.

Данный эпизод в серии Half-Life 2 пожалуй не мой любимый момент истории, ведь на самой неоднозначной ноте Мы получаем завершение истории, которую ожидаем по сей день.

А моя нелюбовь скорее всего связана, виду не слишком большой любви к природному окружению, и огромной симпатии к организации баталий в урабанистических пространствах. По мне, даже старая неоднозначная Devastation (2003) на фоне данного эпизода, была более симпатична, но это исключительно личное предпочтение.

В целом, данное дополнение оригинальной игры раскрывает множество моментов что прекрасно работали в оригинале: это и сражение со страйдерами; и очередные покатушки на машине; а главное очень тесное взаимодействие с Алекс, как в первом эпизоде. Кроме того, побуждающим аспектом к особому восторгу и перепрохождению были достижения, главным из которых можно считать путешествие с самого начала до практически финала игры с гном.

Хотелось бы верить что Valve Corporation однажды продолжат историю данных эпизодов, и главные герои все же доберутся до заветного корабля Барея, но то уже история которая на данный момемнт обладе лишь предпосылками из новинки Half-Life: Alyx (2020), а я Вам рекомендую пройти данный эпизод после завершения основной игры и первого эпизода в обязательном порядке, ведь это безуслновно шдевральный шутер для прохождения и нестареющая классика.

reVote 9/10

Half - Life 2 : Episode Two este un joc video first-person shooter , al doilea episod dintr-o serie de continuări la Half- Life 2.In 2004 a fost dezvoltat de Valve Corporation în tandem cu Episode One , primul joc din serie , și a lansat în 2007 prin platforma de distribuție de conținut Steam Valve . Episodul a fost lansat atât separat, cât și ca parte a unui pachet, pachetul Orange Box.

The better of the two Episodes.

This game is like Half Life 2, except shorter and less special than the main game.
It does have its moments though, and it might be more well thought-out than standard Half-Life 2, now that I think about it.

I just don't like the whole episodic thing they did with these games--it focuses down the Half Life experience too much for my tastes, especially since there isn't really a payoff at the end like with the full titles.

If you liked Episode 1, definitely get this, because it's way better.
Only played Half Life 2? Get both episodes. Despite what I said, you still owe it to yourself to try them yourself. They're not bad or anything, it's just they've got a very "more of what you've already played" vibe as opposed to being something completely new.
Newcomer to the series? Don't start with this. Play Half Life 2 first, or if you really want to, Half Life 1.

Have fun!
Great game series, just wish there was HL3. :)
